Was first introduced to Stardew Valley during the pandemic, and found it to be charming and engaging. Returned to playing as it provides a refuge, an alternative, kinder world to visit when real life is less pleasant. Thoroughly enjoy.

While my hour count is not a abysmal on here as it is on other platforms, I shall leave a review anyways. This was one of the first games I bought with my own money at the ripe ole age of 12. At first, I didn't enjoy it, I didn't understand it. Then I revisited about a year or two later and became obsessed. The consistent loop of farming, mining, and monster killing drew me in. The pleasureful grind sucked me into pure unbridled obsession. The multiple ways of approaching this game kept me coming. When I finally got a PC, the options just opened up. The amount of versatility in modding and creativity is captivating.
The romantic interests are all unique and have wonderful story lines. Each character you meet in this game has their own unique charm that anyone would keep coming back to. Not to mention the update support, with ConcernedApe consistently coming back despite working on another banger of a video game. This game fundamentally changed my life, it carried me through the quarantine, and I wouldn't have it any other way. If you have the spare 15 bucks, please buy this game, trust me it's worth it. You can get hundreds of hours out of this game, even without going full completionist with the achievement and perfection. 10/10 love this game would recommend to anyone listening. 

(Haley my wonderful wife btw)

Stardew Valley has been my favorite farming game for a good five years now. Having played through a new save on Steam and almost reaching perfection again at the time of writing this review, it's just as calming, fun, and open-ended as I remembered. As a gamer with the attention span and general gameplay interests of a caveman, it's pretty crazy that something that appears so mundane and simple at a surface level is one of the most addicting things I've ever played.

This game has been around long enough that the best it has to offer has already been parroted by tons of people, so I'll try to keep the things I love most pretty brief. Progression is perfect and moves at a pace that's simultaneously slow enough that the game always always feels relaxing, yet fast enough that all of the seasonal content the game has to offer returns semi-frequently and it's not quite as agonizing if you accidentally forget to/run out of time to do something during a certain season. NPC townsfolk are designed great, having unique schedules and interests and pretty engaging storylines for the most part. There's a ton of ways you can make money, and with the right setup any of them can be extremely profitable, which makes the gameplay fundamentally super open-ended. That paired with the sheer diversity of things you can do in a single year cycle and the (SPOILER FOR ENDGAME AREA) [spoiler]giant distant island with a colossal amount of unique content you can access late in the game[/spoiler] gives this game a pretty insane longevity that provides hundreds of hours of engagement, and ensures that there's a dozen other projects you can focus on if you can't finish something season-specific.

It's been said by many already, but I can concur that this game has something for everyone. Tons of avenues of farming and ranching for whatever playstyle you have the most fun with, well-designed and fun combat that can be challenging but rarely feels like you're unfairly screwed over, open-ended building and different farm layouts that can allow for breathtakingly beautiful farms, tons of varied NPCs of different age groups you can choose to make friends with or pursue romantically (or not, you can be a sigma lone wolf too, with zero consequences), cross-platform co-op if you'd like to play with a friend or partner, Steam Deck compatibility (which I can't comment further on as I don't have one), and some fun lore that you by no means need to care about at all to enjoy the game but also adds some very welcome charm and mystique to the world if it does interest you, all for the frankly stupid price of only $15 USD. There are very few games that provide this level of content and quality with an indie pricetag, and it's fantastic that we have a charming and relaxing life sim in that boat, as a majority of them tend to lean towards being fast, fun, and high-octane action/adventure/platformer titles. 

There's a million other things to gush about, but I'll leave it at that so as to not spoil anything for anyone. It's worth mentioning I don't play with mods apart from a few small quality-of-life things, but a single browse through Nexus will make it obvious there's a pretty wild modding community working diligently to enhance the game even further. This game is an unbelievably good value for $15, even going on sale occasionally, and comes packaged with so much varied content it's highly unlikely you wouldn't enjoy the game (though I think it also does a good job playing enough of its cards in the first two hours that you'll know very well if this game simply isn't for you and you want to refund it). I can't do anything but strongly recommend giving Stardew a try. The amount of positive reception it continues to get almost a decade after release and its stagnant Overwhelmingly Positive rating on this platform says enough; this game is WELL worth your money. Thank you for helping me through some of the hardest times of my life with your funny little farming game, Mr. Ape.

I can name the following main gameplay reasons to play this game:
Figuring out how to get as much money as possible (and all the systems associated with this process, so treating the game kind of like Factorio)

â€œSocialâ€ element (interactions with 28 unique villager npcs which include but are not limited to talking, trading, helping, dating)
Collection/completionism (I have heard that the steam achievments in this game are among the hardest to complete due to how long that would take, and there is a museum with relic items you can find in the game)
You private property building/decorating (explanation probably not needed, I can note that this was the first time when I didnâ€™t feel overwhelmed by my options)

Fishing (You may snicker at me for making this into itâ€™s own category, especially since this doesnâ€™t really offer anything objectively unique - this is part completionism, part money making and part helping npcs.
Yet I have seen fishing in almost every game I have played recently I start to suspect that there really is a demand for specifically â€œfishingâ€ being in the game, which by the way while seems odd to me should be understandable. 
The fishing minigame in stardew valley itself is similar to other fishing minigames you have played, for example the Genshin one.) 

And lastly the cave/mining gameplay (it is the familiar loop of breaking blocks and killing enemies and finding valuable items from time to time, with the cave changing enemies and scenery every so often, making the player curious what the next biome will be like. This cave gameplay is fairly different from rest of the game which made it stand out to me.)
There were other gameplay loops like the incredibly challenging arcade minigames but I just didnâ€™t consider them being a big enough part to include as a reason to play the game 
But yeah if you end up not liking any of these in the context of the time management element + the interactions with npc then you have no reason to like the game
But you will more likely end up enjoying one or more and enjoy this game!

Alright, listen up. You're probably burned out from getting teabagged by 12-year-olds in shooters or grinding dailies in some soulless MMO. Your soul needs a vacation. Your brain needs a hug. What you need, my friend, is Stardew Valley.

Forget everything you know about farming sims being "boring." This game is a masterpiece of pure, unadulterated dopamine. It's the video game equivalent of a warm blanket and a cup of hot chocolate.

The Grind is... Actually Fun?

The core loop is genius. You start with a dump of a farm, overrun with trees and rocks. It looks like a scene from a post-apocalyptic movie. But then you get your rusty tools, and the magic begins. "Just one more day" becomes your mantra. You'll find yourself saying, "Okay, just gonna water my crops, pet my chickens, maybe go fishing... wait, it's 2 AM in-game and I'm risking passing out to catch one more carp."

Before you know it, you're not just a farmer. You're a artisanal mayonnaise tycoon, a master angler, a legendary monster slayer in the mines, and the town's #1 matchmaker. The skill progression is so satisfying it should be illegal.

Content for Decades

The amount of stuff to do is absolutely bonkers. This isn't just a farming game. It's a:

Â· Dating Sim: Can you woo the goth elf boy or the moody writer? You betcha.
Â· Dungeon Crawler: The mines are no joke! Pack some snacks and a good sword.
Â· Town Restoration Project: Rebuild the community center and stick it to the corporate Joja Mart. Feels good, man.
Â· Fishing RPG: The fishing minigame is a whole vibe and I will fight anyone who says otherwise.

The Verdict: 10/10, A Perfect Comfort Game

But since it doesnâ€™t, I settle for the Valley, where I can pretend Iâ€™m a functional human being by watering digital plants.

And itâ€™s strange because while the real world feels like a chaotic puzzle missing half the pieces, the Valley runs on the kind of common sense I wish society would try sometimes. Plant a seed, water it, andâ€”miracle of miraclesâ€”it actually grows. No existential dread, no sudden plot twist. Just simple, peaceful logic. The loneliness is still there, of course, but somehow it feels lighter when Iâ€™m talking to NPCs who have more emotional depth than half the people I know. Call it escapism if you want, but at this point, it feels more like self-preservation. So yes, maybe Iâ€™m hiding in a tiny pixel farm. Maybe Iâ€™m finding comfort in fake villagers and imaginary crops. I have made repeated attempts over the years to force myself to enjoy this game because people never stop singing its praises. 

I have never managed to see what others evidently do in this game, and I enjoy other games like it a lot. It is allegedly a relaxing, "no pressure" game, but it frustrates at every available opportunity.

Want to go buy seeds? Sorry, it's Wednesday and the shop is arbitrarily closed today!
Want to go and see the blacksmith? Sorry, we're setting up for one of the dozens of festivals today, so you just can't visit half of the map!
Want to visit the desert? Bus driver isn't here today. Or tomorrow, probably. And the day after that, there's another fucking festival, so you can go and eat shit.

JUst a calming, relaxing experience, y'know. You can go at your own pace, as long as the game doesn't decide to just say no to everything you want to do on any given day.

The game is jam packed with arbitrary restrictions and schedules that will constantly stop the player in their tracks, saying "nope, not today". Then there's the constant cutscenes you're forced into with no warning when you just want to do what you were doing. Incredibly wordy, incredibly bland cutscenes. They all go on for far longer than they need to because that's just every game these days, wanting to talk you into a coma. Cause more words is more "content" I guess. More playtime, and more playtime = more value. Apparently.

The characters are all extremely shallow. There is nothing interesting about any of them, so there's no need to bother with talking to them or build relationships other than to check something off a list. To make matters worse, relationship levels decay over time so anyone wanting to keep them high is forced to spend hours running through town throughout a playthrough just finding each one of them and talking to them to hear the same lines of dialogue over and over and over again.

Combat is also shallow and a horrible experience that feels extremely inprecise. Brain-dead easy at times and needlessly punative at others. There seems to be little regard for balance.

I normally love fishing in games. It really sucks in this. Players are foced to spend hours leveling their fishing skill because some fish are quite literally impossible to catch at lower levels. And even when you fully level it, have fun fishing up garbage (literal garbage) much of the time anyway. Just baffling that the dev though this would be satisfying in the least.

Many of the things you can do on the farm are there just to be there. There doesn't really seem to be a need to engage with them beyond busywork and to say that you did it. Keeping the farm free of constantly spawning debris is an insanely tedious chore which would have been enough to make me quit any other game if I wasn't trying to find what people loved to much about this one.

Genuinely one of the most overrated pieces of media ever created, in my opinion, and many of the subsequent games it has inspired (and there are MANY) are superior in virtually every way. I'm still continually baffled and the amount of hype this gets. There's not need to play it over countless other games out there that just do it all better.

The only exceptional thing about this game is that it was made by one person. There is credit due for that, at least.

As for the visuals - I get the nostalgic appeal of the retro pixel art. But personally, I found the world a little gloomy and lifeless. Thatâ€™s totally a taste thing, and I respect the creative choice. It just didnâ€™t do much for me.

Stardew Valley 
(Disclaimer - This is just my opinion and may be unpopular or disliked. Also, I played a game called Palia, which reminded me of this first and will be referencing that below.)

(General)
1. This is a pixel art life simulation game with elements of farming and dating.
2. The game is mostly cozy, but can require some think work.
3. Game can be played solo or with up to 8 players including you for PC.

(Positive)
1. The game is pixel art and that given me the nostalgia of old games.
2. The game is mostly cozy and can be something you just play to chill.
3. There is charater diversity and a lot of decent amount of dating options. 
4. I see the similaraties in Palia to this game and enjoyed that as I liked Palia.


(Negative)
1. The game can get lengthy.
2. If I played this before Palia, Palia would've just been an improvement to it. (Due to this the game was just not that smooth to me).
3. Settings options, inventory, etc is limited and not expanded enough on.
4. Farming due to seasons and crop rotaions and fishing can sometimes be difficult and need quite a bit of think work taking away from the cozy atmosphere.
5. The game really just wasn't for me and I found it to be tedious and needing work.

I have made repeated attempts over the years to force myself to enjoy this game because people never stop singing its praises. 

I have never managed to see what others evidently do in this game, and I enjoy other games like it a lot. It is allegedly a relaxing, "no pressure" game, but it frustrates at every available opportunity.

Want to go buy seeds? Sorry, it's Wednesday and the shop is arbitrarily closed today!
Want to go and see the blacksmith? Sorry, we're setting up for one of the dozens of festivals today, so you just can't visit half of the map!
Want to visit the desert? Bus driver isn't here today. Or tomorrow, probably. And the day after that, there's another fucking festival, so you can go and eat shit.

JUst a calming, relaxing experience, y'know. You can go at your own pace, as long as the game doesn't decide to just say no to everything you want to do on any given day.

The game is jam packed with arbitrary restrictions and schedules that will constantly stop the player in their tracks, saying "nope, not today". Then there's the constant cutscenes you're forced into with no warning when you just want to do what you were doing. Incredibly wordy, incredibly bland cutscenes. They all go on for far longer than they need to because that's just every game these days, wanting to talk you into a coma. Cause more words is more "content" I guess. More playtime, and more playtime = more value. Apparently.

The characters are all extremely shallow. There is nothing interesting about any of them, so there's no need to bother with talking to them or build relationships other than to check something off a list. To make matters worse, relationship levels decay over time so anyone wanting to keep them high is forced to spend hours running through town throughout a playthrough just finding each one of them and talking to them to hear the same lines of dialogue over and over and over again.

Combat is also shallow and a horrible experience that feels extremely inprecise. Brain-dead easy at times and needlessly punative at others. There seems to be little regard for balance.

I normally love fishing in games. It really sucks in this. Players are foced to spend hours leveling their fishing skill because some fish are quite literally impossible to catch at lower levels. And even when you fully level it, have fun fishing up garbage (literal garbage) much of the time anyway. Just baffling that the dev though this would be satisfying in the least.

Many of the things you can do on the farm are there just to be there. There doesn't really seem to be a need to engage with them beyond busywork and to say that you did it. Keeping the farm free of constantly spawning debris is an insanely tedious chore which would have been enough to make me quit any other game if I wasn't trying to find what people loved to much about this one.

Genuinely one of the most overrated pieces of media ever created, in my opinion, and many of the subsequent games it has inspired (and there are MANY) are superior in virtually every way. I'm still continually baffled and the amount of hype this gets. There's not need to play it over countless other games out there that just do it all better.

The only exceptional thing about this game is that it was made by one person. There is credit due for that, at least.
